fields.description: Some of the statistical information that Bamboo provides is sensitive for some groups. Providing a choice to disable it or restrict who can view it would be very good idea, IMO
fields.summary: Restrict access to statistics

fields.description: At present, if multiple errors show up, you have to close them individually. Personally, they're all usually always related, ie they're either multiple artifacts that have failed because a build failed (one error per artifact) or we have a server space issue and every build throws an error about it. In any case, if all the issues have been dealt with, it would much nicer to be able to clear all the errors in one swoop rather than having to clear each one individually.
fields.summary: Clear all errors option

Cannot retrieve test issue from JIRA Server: java.net.MalformedURLException: no protocol: jira.us.packetmotion.com/rpc/soap/jirasoapservice-v2

fields.description:
When a build completes, it's supposed to copy artifacts (as I understand it). Unfortunately this doesn't work for us - and returns an error as follows.


(Failed to copy /home/bamboo-server/home/xml-data/build-dir/APP-MAIN/output/db/classes/com/networks/db/DatabaseRuntimeException.class to /home/bamboo-server/home/xml-data/builds/APP-MAIN/download-data/artifacts/build-55/output/db/classes/com/networks/db/DatabaseRuntimeException.class due to /home/bamboo-server/home/xml-data/build-dir/APP-MAIN/output/db/classes/com/networks/db/DatabaseRuntimeException.class (No such file or directory))


Now admittedly I don't need the .class file to be copied, but it's just easier to configure that way (so I get everything), and I can't see why it wouldn't be copied.

I've checked that the .class file in question exists - and it does (I can't guarantee it exists when the copy occurs, but there's nothing magic in the build - so I'd wager it does exist).

The configuration I use in the build configuration is:

Label  	Source Directory  	Copy Pattern
output 	output 	**/*

Am I dumb, or is something amiss?
fields.summary: Unable to copy build artifacts

fields.description:
i'd like to be able to define a threshhold on build time that makes the build count as a failure.  Probably defined as a percentage of average.

I currently have a build that locks up horribly from from time to time.  

It would be great if it could be automatically killed and counted as a failure whenver the build time gets to twice the average, or 30 minutes past the average, or even 100 minutes (regardless of the average).

fields.description:
You may remember that opensource.bamboo.atlassian.com would fail to build struts2, failing because java couldn't be found by sub-processes.  This was fixed by explicitly setting the path to include the default java.

However this raises the question of whether the build/tests are being run with the correct java SDK.  For example, if I have JDK1.5 installed system-wide but nominate to build with JDK1.4 it is likely that JDK1.5 will run unit-tests (and possibly build the project?) rather than the nominated build environment, as maven2 doesn't explicitly specify the java executable path, and the default javac/java will be picked-up.

A possible solution is to add the $JAVA__HOME/bin to the start of the path.
fields.summary: Bamboo may pickup wrong java installation in sub-processes

fields.description:
Currently, I have three separate numbers that indicate the version of the software being built:

1) The Subversion revision number
2) The Bamboo build number
3) The application build number (which is held in a properties file that Bamboo updates on every build)

I want all of these to come from Subversion.  This means that:

 - Bamboo should obtain and hold the revision number when it does an 'svn up'
 - Bamboo should use this as the build number
 - Bamboo should (ideally by default) pass this number to Ant so that I can use it as a substitution value during the build.
fields.summary: Make it possible to use the Subversion revision number as the build number

fields.summary: "Cannot find or execute 'null' at 'null' " while trying to create a new build
Additional Build Strategies

fields.description:
I like the new project/build hierarchy, but I think the terminology is somewhat confusing.  We have a project, which can consist of several builds, and then Bamboo tracks several individual builds for each build.  Similarly, there's a project summary page, which lists all of its builds.  Then there's a build summary page, from which you can jump to individual build result pages.  

So it seems like its hard to distinguish in the terminology between a build (part of a project) and a build (individual, numbered result).  

I'm not exactly sure what would be better, but I do know that the word "build" usually implies an event, not a long lived object in a hierarchy.  So I'd like to use a different term for the builds that are part of a project in the hierarchy -- perhaps something like "sub-projects" or "components"?
fields.summary: Project/Build Terminology Confusing
Use 307 response code instead of meta-refresh when hitting path of bamboo

fields.description:
We are seeing instances where the building hangs because one build did not receive response from CVS server.

We should implement a timeout mechanism to ensure this doesn't happen.
fields.summary: Building hangs if one build does not get response from source repository.

fields.description:
I'm trying to put Bamboo behind our Apache setup like this:

  ProxyPass /bamboo http://127.0.0.1:8085
  ProxyPassReverse /bamboo http://127.0.0.1:8085

But this results in broken links within Bamboo. The reason is that for this to work we need to be able to configure the web app root in bamboo. It would be nice if this were also possible for the standalone version.
fields.summary: Ability to configure the web root for bamboo (for hosting behind Apache)

fields.description:
Bamboo reports: Build 10 had a total of 13626 tests.

While Maven on the command line correctly says:

Tests run: 311, Failures: 8, Errors: 6, Skipped: 0

I also noticed this when building some open source projects like Wicket or OpenJPA.
fields.summary: Bamboo shows incorrect number of tests

fields.description:
On the viewTestCase screen (getting there via the 'View test case across builds' link) shows two graphs: 'Succesful VS Failed builds' and 'Test Running Duration'. In the latter, the vertical label is wrong. Should be 'Run Time' instead of 'Build Time'.

 S.
fields.summary: Wrong title on 'Test Running Duration' graph

fields.description: Some open source projects like Jetty, Wicket or OpenJPA have a large number of unit tests. Think about hundreds or even thousands. Selecting the 'tests' report is in those cases extremely slow since it takes a lot of time to build up a huge page. It would be nice if in those cases the unit tests were paginated, summarized, or dynamically loaded through AJAX. This is in the viewBuildResultsTests.action screen.
fields.summary: Better handling of large number of unit tests

fields.description: I know it is possible to link to an external system that allows you to browse the subversion repository but it would be really nice if Bamboo would have this build in. I can imagine this as a [Show Diff] link in the viewBuildCommits.action screen which would then load the diff and put it in the page trhough AJAX. (Because you probably don't want to show a page with 500 big diffs)
fields.summary: Integrated Source/Diff browser

fields.description: Just like JIRA's private mode: users have to login first before they can see the Bamboo dashboard.
fields.summary: Ability to run a Bamboo in 'private mode'

fields.description: Just like you can use JIRA to manage your Confluence users. I would like the same for Bamboo instead of having to maintain multiple user databases.
fields.summary: Ability to use JIRA's user/group database

fields.description:
When creating a build and configuring artifacts, the cancel link actually does nothing.
Similarly configuring artifacts post build, the cancel link does nothing.

However, if validation fails when configuring artifacts post build, the configuration options disappear and hence you can't go back.
fields.summary: configuring artifacts - links that do nothing and navigation

fields.description: Was trying to define a new build that uses Perforce. Encountered the attached error after step 2.
fields.summary: Server error creating build

Something I noticed looking at the logs is that indexing isn't a standalone process:

{noformat}
2006-11-23 10:35:09,005 INFO [http-8080-Processor2] [DefaultTestCaseResultsIndexer] Indexing build ... CTO33, took: 408
2006-11-23 10:35:09,203 INFO [http-8080-Processor2] [DefaultTestCaseResultsIndexer] Indexing build ... CTO32, took: 148

2006-11-23 10:35:10,349 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM]       [sql] 3415 of 3415 SQL statements executed successfully
2006-11-23 10:35:10,465 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM]       [sql] Executing file: /apps/WebSphere/Portal/tomcat/jakarta-tomcat-5.0.28/bin/build-dir/NEM/src/sql/release1.13/alterNemUserTable.sql
2006-11-23 10:35:10,494 INFO [http-8080-Processor2] [DefaultTestCaseResultsIndexer] Indexing build ... CTO27, took: 198
2006-11-23 10:35:10,566 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM]       [sql] 5 of 5 SQL statements executed successfully
2006-11-23 10:35:10,585 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM] 
2006-11-23 10:35:10,586 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM] echo-jdbc-config:
2006-11-23 10:35:10,586 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM]      [echo] 
2006-11-23 10:35:10,586 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM]      [echo]             ***** Rebuilding Databases *****
2006-11-23 10:35:10,586 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM]      [echo]             CAT JDBC URL: xxx
2006-11-23 10:35:10,586 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM]      [echo]             NEM JDBC URL: xx
2006-11-23 10:35:10,586 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM]      [echo]             ********************************
2006-11-23 10:35:10,587 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM]      [echo]         
2006-11-23 10:35:10,587 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM] 
2006-11-23 10:35:10,587 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM] release:
2006-11-23 10:35:10,620 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM]       [sql] Executing file: xxx
2006-11-23 10:35:10,716 INFO [output stream pumper] [StreamToListPumper] [NEM]       [sql] 4 of 4 SQL statements executed successfully
2006-11-23 10:35:11,520 INFO [http-8080-Processor2] [DefaultTestCaseResultsIndexer] Indexing build ... CTO26, took: 985
2006-11-23 10:35:12,138 INFO [http-8080-Processor2] [DefaultTestCaseResultsIndexer] Indexing build ... CTO25, took: 224
2006-11-23 10:35:13,168 INFO [http-8080-Processor2] [DefaultTestCaseResultsIndexer] Indexing build ... CTO24, took: 686
{noformat}

Due to a) the indexing taking ages as is and b) indexing as a concept being fragile if the data being indexed changes, wouldn't it be a better performance enhancement if all the builds were disabled while indexing took place, then re-enabled on completion? Would reduce the time the web page sits pretending to do something which you think is solely the indexing, while it's actually running away building, which I would hope wouldn't happen. And with the app being inaccessible during indexing, I'd hope the builds were inaccessible too (ie they shouldn't be able to run)

fields.description:
It would be nice to have the ability to kick a dependent build off on a remote server.  We currently have a process we wrote that will run Perforce jobs we create during our main build.  Our main build is on a linux server and we run more functional tests on another windows server.  For us it would be nice if bamboo would be able to kick off the windows build after the linux build completed.

You could maybe take this a step further and have the ability to setup a clustered build environment that would allow you to specify a number of servers and then let you specify which builds can run on which server.

Please let me know if you need more details.
fields.summary: Starting builds on multiple servers

fields.description:
just ran through your installation.

put the bamboo home from the previous admin entry as you said in your upgrade script:

bamboo.home=C:\dev\work-dir\devbamboo

and started the app - shows up as 

Bamboo Home: C:\dev\bamboo\devwork-dirdevbamboo 

didn't pick any builds up or anything.

If I put in exactly what was there before:

C:\dev\bamboo

it correctly sets itself within the app to:

C:\dev\bamboo\devbamboo

the app reference is different to the bamboo-init.properties entry - not a direct link but a generated on based on the bamboo home string. Also found the upgrade guide a bit confusing - you said 'directory contains the BAMBOO_HOME line with with the absolute path to your Bamboo Home directory' - so should it contain the string 'BAMBOO_HOME' or the absolute path (ie c:\dev\bamboo)? Wasn't sure
fields.summary: bamboo.home incorrect

fields.description:
Two things:

1) your upgrade screen says 'If you have builds with CVS or SVN repositories and were being being triggered'. Should read 'If you have builds with CVS or SVN repositories and they were being triggered'

2) my builds are poll based. Still wacked both source folders and created new ones names XXX-MAIN. Think you should mention that if you build using SVN or CVS regardless of method the project should be renamed. We never used triggers on the box i'm upgrading.

fields.description:
A new build reports feature which allows viewing of trends of key build metrics:

- number of builds
- number of failures
- ratio of successful builds
- number of tests
- duration of build.

The reports shall allow comparison of different builds on these metrics.

Data points can be grouped by time periods:
- Day
- Week
- Month.

fields.description:
Seems to have been changed in the 0.7 release on keg. Please change it back!

People tend to remember projects by name and therefore scan the list by name, not by key. At first glance the list looks like a complete jumble because the names aren't in order.
fields.summary: Dashboard ordered by project key rather than name

fields.description:
At the moment tests detect that they were "broken" from the first time they appear in the "broken tests" list. The result of this is that if you have

| BAM-MAIN-1 | Buld Succesful |
| BAM-MAIN-2 | test.foo failed |
| BAM-MAIN-3 | Compilation failed (no tests ran) |
| BAM-MAIN-4 | test.foo failed |

test.foo actually reports as having been failing since BAM-MAIN-4. It should be intelligent enough to see that it hasn't been in the "successful" test list since BAM-MAIN-1.
fields.summary: Tests detect when they start failing more intelligently

fields.description: Clearing the checkbox doesn't really work. We need to make sure that if nothing is passed, the action sets the Build Expiry property to false
fields.summary: Cannot disable Build Expiry

fields.description: You can now view builds associated with JIRA issues. It would be good to see summarised data for such builds so you can see what effects the issue had on the source base (e.g. Did we add 50 tests with the issue? Did the issue slow down the build by two minutes?)
fields.summary: Aggregate build statistics based on JIRA issues

fields.description: Include other useful batches (install-as-service, etc.)
fields.summary: Include other useful batches (install-as-service, etc.) in installation

fields.description:
When kicking off a manual build for the RSVP-plugin (or for any build for that matter), it does not pick up the changes in the source repository. 

Given that a person kicks off a manual build when he can't be bothered to wait for the changes to be detected, it's not so much of an issue. However, the history no longer reflects all the changes made on that build.
fields.summary: Manual build does not pick up changes

fields.description: Most of our checkins are to CVS branches where the repository records the change in the special "Attic" directory.  This is propagating into Bamboo, where the ViewCVS/Fisheye links contain the "Attic/" path in them, thus they are broken.  Could you filter file paths for the Attic and remove it?
fields.summary: Code change filenames from CVS branch have "Attic" in the path

fields.description:
Calling "/api/rest/getLatestBuildResults.action" on a project when it's building returns an HTTP 502 status code.

I know the server is busy building, but it should still be able to return the build status.
fields.summary: Calling "/api/rest/getLatestBuildResults.action" on a project when it's building returns an HTTP 502 status code.

fields.description:
A few page titles could be improved in Bamboo:

1. View Authors: ": Authors - Bamboo Continuous Integration Server". All the authors section seems to have broken page titles at the moment. Should there be something before the colon?

2. Dashboard: "The Bamboo Build System - Bamboo Continuous Integration Server". Are you a build system or a continuous integration server? Should this include dashboard or home, if that's what the page is?

3. All the page titles are too long with 'Bamboo Continuous Integration Server' at the end. It's only the first time someone visits Bamboo that they won't know what it actually is, and page titles are used more regularly than that (bookmarks, delicious, etc). Either 'Atlassian Bamboo' or just 'Bamboo' would suffice; that's what JIRA and Confluence have by default.
fields.summary: Improve page titles

fields.description: Most places in Bamboo now use the profile name for a user where it is available. However, the list of authors doesn't.
fields.summary: Use profile names on View Authors page

See also BAM-416, because this build should not be an error.

fields.description:
Thanks to buugs like http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MSUREFIRE-114, sometimes the XML created by the builds can't be trusted.

We should ensure that test case result objects are stored in a set so that they can't have duplicates. This should be done at build time, so any builds that have already been completed will not be affected. Maybe we could look at an upgrade task afterwards.
fields.summary: Bamboo should ensure test uniqueness within a build

I prefer jumping to the view page first, then switching tabs to select which bit to edit.

Cannot be cleared by unchecking the "Send an email" box and saving. When you return to the page, the checkbox is checked and the specified recipients are still there.

Similarly for IMs it still saves the groups to message although it does clear the checkbox.

fields.description: When editing a project, the project will build on saving. However, the resulting build will contain all the code change data since the beginning of the module.
fields.summary: Build edits trigger builds with ALL code changes

fields.description:
[Raised on behalf of Randy]

Hi Edwin,

I haven't tried the 0.6 release yet, but I'm glad to see the start of a JIRA integration.  I just wanted to mention that it would be nice if this integration worked like the JIRA Perforce plug-in for users of Perforce.  That is, instead of referencing a JIRA issue number in a check-in comment, it would use Perforce jobs that are linked to JIRA issues. 

Cheers,
Randy DeFauw
fields.summary: Commits in Perforce repository link to JIRA issues via Perforce Jobs

fields.summary: Update images on Confluence

fields.description:
I tried to configure a JIRA server to test the new integration feature.  I entered the details of a test JIRA instance running locally, and gave it a sample issue ID.  When I used the 'test' feature, it spit out an XML error.  I'm attaching the log file to this run.

I assume that this error is preventing the 'Changes' feature from working properly; I didn't see my check-in comments from Perforce there.
fields.summary: Unable to get change logs for Perforce
